Review: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice

For Ian Lunny, Batman v Superman never manages to build on its individual good moments, and becomes an exercise in wasted potential

Review: Hail, Caesar!

Angel Lloyd is charmed by aspects of Hail Caesar, but proposes it may have worked better as a series of short films rather than a full length feature.

Review: The Witch

Lauren McNeilage is entranced by the tension and dread in The Witch

Review: The Forest

Lazy, poorly paced, and ultimately disrespectful, The Forest is nowhere near as clever as it thinks it is

Preview: The Great Yorkshire Bank Robbery

Lauren McNeilage takes a look at an upcoming short film, filmed and set in York

Review: Pride and Prejudice and Zombies

Pride and Prejudice and Zombies is a deliciously silly romp that's basically everything you would expect from its title, says Lauren McNeilage

Review: Triple 9

A flat and derivative police corruption thriller, Triple 9 is weighed down by an over-stuffed, charmless script and a wasted pool of acting talent, says Louis Chilton

Review: Deadpool

Deadpool is a brilliantly refreshing take on the superhero genre. Its sarcastic humour and gory visuals make it the perfect film adaptation of the beloved comic-book anti-hero, says Liam Dooley

Review: Youth

Youth is intelligent, inventive cinema, as unashamedly playful as it is deceptively meaningful, says Louis Chilton

Review: The Big Short

The Big Short could very well be heading for Oscar glory in a few weeks time, so we thought it fitting to feature a second perspective on this comedic look at history and the economy, this time from Jonathan Legrand

Review: Spotlight

Adam Kelly considers Spotlight an excellent film, which informs and grips you, whilst never getting in the way of the real, tragic story being told

Review: The Big Short

With The Big Short, Adam McKay manages to find engaging cinema in profoundly un-cinematic material, says Louis Chilton.

Review: The Revenant

Simran Virdee praises the immervie nature of The Revenant, calling it a cold, bleak, desolate, painful and overwhelming assault on the senses

Review: The Hateful Eight

Adam Kelly offers our final take on The Hateful Eight. He calls it "a cocktail of thrills, laughs, mystery, his unique Tarantino speak and essential over-the-top violence."

Review: The Hateful Eight

Jonathan Legrand offers our second take on Tarantino's latest saying, only the likes of Hitchcock's Psycho equals the suspense portrayed in Minnie's Tavern.

Review: The Hateful Eight

Simran Virdee praises the script while bemoaning the lack of his usually innovative filmmaking, in the first of three reviews of The Hateful Eight.

Review: Joy

Joy is a timeless story of perseverance and ambition that will join the ranks of great women driven biopics, says Angel Lloyd.

Review: Star Wars - The Force Awakens

Thomas Shutt calls The Force Awakens (2015's biggest commerical hit) a thrilling and entertaining experience, even as it relies on many familiar tropes

Review: Sunset Song

This adaption of the Lewis Grassic Gibbon novel of the same name has incredible cinematography but a lacking plot, says Angel Lloyd

Review: Black Mass

Laura Hancock praises Black Mass which may lack complexity, but boasts a solid narrative structure and a host of great performances

Review: Brooklyn

Brooklyn is special for many reasons, but principally for the chance to watch the maturation of Saoirse Ronan, says Andrew Kendall

Review: Krampus

Krampus has a lot of fun moments, but Lauren McNeilage finds it doesn't do much justice to its source material

Review: Carol

Carol is an intense, slow-burning romance that will linger on the tip of cinema's tongue, says Laura Hancock

Review: Sicario

Andrew Kendall praises Sicario, Denis Villeneuve's distillation of drug-war tensions between lawbreakers and law enforces

The Rocky Horror Picture Show: Forty Years Later

Jack Richardson takes a look at The Rocky Horror Picture Show's legacy and relevance forty years after its debut

Kate Weedy reviews one of her favourites from the Aesthetica Short Film Festival

Review: Burnt

Bradley Cooper plays an arrogant man-child with anger issues in a bland and predictable film, says Lauren McNeilage

Review: Me and Earl and the Dying Girl

Malou Van Rooij takes a look at how Me & Earl and the Dying Girl subverts the familiar tropes to pack an emotional wallop

The 2015 Aesthetica Experience (Part One)

Coco Clements gives a personal account of the whirlwind experience of the 2015 Aesthetica Film Festival
